instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PPV5_S0: What is PPV5_S0? This is a typo of PP5V_S0 When you see PPV5_S0, assume they meant to type PP5V_S0.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
hello

having a strange thing with a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (diffrent one from the one solved a few days ago)

after liquid damage, had a hard short to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
the short to ground was solved by replacing the two mosfets - <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7320</TRANSISTOR> from a donor board..

now i get 12.54v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

still missing the rails
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PPV5_S0</SIGNAL> (come and goes, could be a bad <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>, don't have another to test currently, as of now showing 0.40v)
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3</SIGNAL> - 0v


i got the fan spinning in some point, but no chime or sign of life.

could be damage to the cpu due to the short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>?
advice on what to troubleshoot next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: If <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR> was shorted, then the CPU got 12 volts. RIP.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
hi john

actually the one that was making the short was the other mosfet - <TRANSISTOR>Q7320</TRANSISTOR>, when i pulled him out the short was gone..
i replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR> just in case.. does that make any diffrence? or still RIP for the cpu?

also,
i notice now that when i plug in the charger i get <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3</SIGNAL> 3.3v for a few seconds and than it's gone..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: If that one shorted, maybe a chance, but I doubt it. Replace <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7311</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7320</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7321</TRANSISTOR>, and <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> all at the same time and pray the CPU didn't get killed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
thanks both...

is that the case in any <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> short involving the cpu mosfet?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Any "high side" FET shorting from PPBUS to any rail will usually destroy everything on that rail. So a shorted high side FET in many cases is hopeless. CPU Vcore is just a very common one and the CPU is easily killed.
